Message.Title: Exposing the myth of Republican superiority in business and economics
Message.Msg: The Business Section of today' Boston Globe contains an article comparing the past performance of the economy under Democratic and Republican administrations using three metrics: economic growth (median GDP), average annual stock market growth (S&P500), and increase in corporate earnings. The numbers are startling, and completely contrary to the widespread myth of Republican business superiority. Since 1949, the GDP grew at an average annual rate of 4.2% under Democratic administrations (Truman thru Obama), but at a 2.6% rate under Republican administrations (Eisenhower thru Bush II) Since 1913, the stock market grew at an average annual rate of 12.1% under Democratic administrations (and 12.3% during Obama's tenure), but a 5.1% rate under Republican administrations. Finally, the average annual increase in corporate earnings since 1936 was 10.5% under Democratic leadership, a whopping 51.8% under Obama, and only 8.9% under Republicans presidents. Romney's claim that he would grow the economy at an annual rate of 4% is dubious at best, given that from 1953 to present, no Republican president has ever achieved or surpassed that goal. The GOP has a glaring tendency to dismiss math from their political and economic calculations, which only further undermines their claim to superior business acumen and performance. It is a myth perpetuated by business owners and CEOs and corporate directors, because they understand that their bread is buttered not by the performance of their businesses, but by the growth of their own personal wealth. Message.Title: Bac Best in Branch Service.
Message.Msg: Bank of America has been recognized for providing the best in-branch experience for a new customer by Celent, a leading bank consulting firm. The award follows extensive research by the Boston-based firm in which it sent researchers to open accounts at all major banks in the U.S. In addition to BofA, BB&T and SunTrust were among Charlotte banks that received high marks. When the researcher tried to open an account at a BofA branch, the Charlotte-based bank offered a mortgage review, credit card assessment, investment account overview and information on savings accounts. “The XCelent Service Award goes to Bank of America, with an honorable mention to BB&T. They conducted the most thorough needs assessment by a long shot. The entire visit took an hour and involved a platform staff member, an investment manager, and the branch manager,” the report says. “Retail branch banking is fundamentally a people business, and it was a team of people at Bank of America that won the day with their XCelent Service award. From the most thorough needs assessment to demonstrating ATMs to having an investment specialist on site, they were able to offer the broadest array of solutions on the spot,” the report continues. “Great training or maybe just great people at BB&T and SunTrust also helped these two banks drive customer-focused needs assessment to help bankers think like customers.”

Message.Title: FTC axes fake caller “Rachel from Cardholder Services”...thank u FTC!!
Message.Msg: “Rachel from Cardholder Services” may not be calling you anymore. A federal court order Thursday morning temporarily halted operations at five telemarketing firms that the Federal Trade Commission said illegally dialed up consumers with millions of prerecorded messages – often saying they were from “Rachel.” “ ‘Rachel from Cardholder Services’ is public enemy No. 1,” FTC Chairman Jon Leibowitz said in a statement. The FTC receives 200,000 complaints a month about robocalls. The agency has shut down companies responsible for 2.6 billion telemarketing calls since such calls were outlawed in 2009, but that’s a drop in the bucket, FTC said. The agency says it can’t trace or block about 59 percent of phone spam because the calls route through a tangle of automatic dialers, caller ID spoofing and voice-over-Internet protocols. The problem is so bad that earlier this month the FTC offered a $50,000 prize to anyone who could come up with a way to stop telephonic spam. wThe contest runs until Jan. 17. FTC said the “Rachel” telemarketing companies, all based in Arizona and Florida, told consumers that they could drastically reduce their credit card interest rates if they paid initial fees. Asking for such an up-front fee for debt-reduction services is illegal, the FTC said. Calls from “Rachel” told listeners that there was an “important message” for them regarding high credit card interest rates, the FTC said. Listeners were then told to press 1 to speak with an operator, or 2 to stop getting the calls. Pressing 1 led consumers to a live telemarketer, some of whom promised to save consumers up to $2,500 in finance charges or pay off their credit card balances faster by using the company’s service, the FTC said. If consumers said they were interested, the telemarketing company then conducted an “audit” to make sure the customer qualified, according to the complaint filed by the FTC. That usually required the consumer giving out credit card and financial information over the phone. The fee for the interest-reduction service ranged from several hundred dollars to $3,000, the FTC said. In some cases, consumers were charged without their consent. In others, the telemarketers did not disclose that there was a fee. In the complaint, the FTC said the companies were violating various consumer protection laws including misrepresenting to consumers that their services would save them money and reduce credit card interest rates.

Topic.Title: ONLY 3 DAYS FOR OBAMA TO GET MANDATE!

Message.Msg: I think Obama has turned the corner on the chapter of his life when he used to go on man dates. The 3 boyfriends in Chicago died, one from a car "accident", the other 2 murdered "execution-style". Odd, isn't it. Execution style. Almost like it was planned to keep a secret... a secret. Buddy Love is all that's left of that chapter. Another odd coincidence on the name, don't you agree? Your "great president" doesn't measure up to any real measure of greatness. It's amazing to me that you are celebrating when the propaganda machine is still cranking, still trying to pull in the vote necessary to push O back near the top. In case you weren't aware, that means your guy is behind. And not by a little. By a lot. So, let's look at the state of the election: Yes, polls have been coming out saying it's all neck and neck, a real barnstormer of a race. But we both know that isn't true at all, don't we. Obama's voters aren't showing up at the polls. And Romney's are. In huge numbers. Up by a tremendous amount from 2008. Before election day, even. You would do well to recall -- if you ever knew -- that Obama lost the election day vote. The only thing that saved him was early voting. Well, early voting has turned up a huge number of Romney supporters this time, and some 30% fewer for Obama. In the close states, it's really neck and neck. Advantage Romney. And Sandy cannot unwind those votes. And nobody is going to get juiced to go to the polls on election day on the basis that "wow, did you see how presidential he looked before he put on his Bush-like bomber jacket and took off for Las Vegas like he did after Benghazi"... No, if anything, that'll just encourage them that he's already in there, and they'll stay home. Besides, a lot of his voters can't find food, water or gasoline, despite hearing that Obama did a fly-over, a la W. Bush. But then, you wouldn't want them to vote in their current state of mind -- they might just vote for the other guy. The election, from my perspective, is really pretty much over, and I'm not sure what you'll be celebrating, but you should be celebrating the end of a disaster (I know I will), even if you weren't smart enough to realize that Obama's administration has been nothing short of an epic disaster. Like Sandy. And like Sandy, the worst parts won't show up until shortly after he's left the scene. In his Bush-like bomber jacket.

Topic.Title: Gee 4 years ago p krugman told us we need north of 350K jobs per month to stay even

Message.Msg: But here's a great start at that list you're looking for, this one attributed to John Lott: It is important to realize just how terrible Krugman’s record has been. He predicted on CNBC: “I am still guessing that we will peak out at around 9 percent [unemployment] and that would be late this year.” He assured listeners that double-digit unemployment was “not the most likely event” and “Actually, we are already seeing some positive effects [from the Stimulus].” With unemployment peaking at 10.1 percent and still above 9 percent over two-and-a-half years after he predicted it would peak, Krugman was wrong on both counts. Krugman’s predictions were also filled with personal attacks against those with whom he disagreed. In March 2009, when Greg Mankiw, the chair of George W. Bush’s Council of Economic Advisers, and some conservative economists questioned what they called Obama’s “overly optimistic” growth predictions, Paul Krugman questioned their honesty. In a New York Times blog post titled the “Roots of Evil,” Krugman attacked Mankiw as “more than a bit of deliberate obtuseness” and that “we can expect fast growth.” Yet, our economic growth has not even come close to what Obama and Krugman predicted. It has also been much slower than past economic recoveries. This last year Obama predicted that GDP would grow at 4 percent, while in fact it was less than half of that -- just 1.7 percent. Mankiw challenged Krugman to a bet over whether the Obama prediction was right, but, despite all Krugman’s abusive rhetoric, he never responded. Krugman must be glad that he never bet his money to back up his claims of “evil” or “deliberate” misinformation, but he never tempered his rhetoric. Amazingly, despite his track record against conservatives, Krugman didn’t flinch in late 2010 when he claimed: “It’s also worth pointing out that everything the right said about why Obamanomics would fail was wrong.” Krugman’s predictions were no more accurate for other countries. He criticized the reduction in German government spending in June 2010 as a “huge mistake,” and said: “budget cuts will hurt your economy and reduce revenues [by reducing economic growth].”Yet, more than a year later, Germany’s unemployment rate continued falling, dropping by 0.7 percentage points between June 2010 and August 2011. And as of June 2011, German GDP during 2011 grew at 3 percent, almost twice as fast as our own GDP growth. Germany accomplished the lower unemployment and higher growth rates without burdening its children with the massively higher debt that Obama and Krugman advocated. But you get some idea why Krugman predictions have so been consistently wrong by understanding that he just thinks government spending is free. He also thought that the 9/11 attacks “could even do some economic good” by stimulating the economy because “all of a sudden, we need some new office buildings” and “rebuilding will generate at least some increase in business spending.” Let’s the buildings and spend the money on something else. Digging ditches and filling them in again leaves people no better off. Krugman has a different view: “If we discovered that space aliens were planning to attack and we needed a massive buildup to counter the space alien threat and really inflation and budget deficits took secondary place to that, this slump would be over in 18 months. And then if we discovered, oops, we made a mistake, there aren’t any aliens, we’d be better off.” The federal government’s publicly held debt has almost doubled in just over three years. How many more rosy predictions coming from Paul Krugman can we afford?

Message.Msg: Listen Reggie - if you spent 5 minutes looking at what Obama could possibly attain from doing what he's doing, and then see what Romney could lose from doing what he's doing, you'd have a first class understanding of human motivation. The only thing Romney's gonna gain from doing what he pledges is a population who could care less about him and who focus intently on being independent. Obama's motivation always puts himself at the center, as the head of state. He's putting government front and center as the be-all end-all of human existence. He can't see you functioning without him, and I am convinced he doesn't want you functioning without him, and he may not let you function with (or without) him. It's not about lies, Reggie. If it were, you'd never even mention O's name. It's about the motivation. And O's motivation is as pure as Stalin's love for his enemies. R gets nothing from the deal if he wins and fixes it all. You think the press will ever give him credit, even if he does fix it? Heck no. So he's gonna lose personally, either way. Can't get hurt financially. A guy who's got a few hundred mil tucked away isn't worried about his taxes, I can tell you right now. It's just not motivating and it isn't plausible. He's worried about either his legacy or his constituency, which includes his progeny. O, on the other hand, is out to prove something else entirely. You don't go down the road he's riding without a serious intent to inflict some change, and it's not the kind of change that spreads joy and peace and happiness. It spreads misery by lopping off the right side of the bell and shifting everything left. Only you can't ever get rid of the right tail -- it's always gonna exist. So the poor get poorer, the middle class get poorer, and the wealthy get poorer but are still wealthy. And everyone suffers from envy disorders. Case in point: Mayor of Bridgeport stirs up his folks, talks about the well-off are getting their power restored faster than us, and we're bigger customers and should come first. When United Illuminated shows up in Bridgeport, the locals throw eggs and rocks and stuff at 'em. They leave, without restoring power. They come back later, but the mayor had to provide police escorts for all of the workers. What good came from inciting the class envy riots? It resulted in longer delays to restore power, it pulled cops off serious anti-looting duty, it spread misery to the utility workers, and it gained zero benefit for the participants. That's what Obama does. Why does that make you happy, again?

Topic.Title: SOLD MY SHARES TODAY

Message.Msg: Considering the share prices of BAC and the upward trend of the market the last couple of years, I certainly wouldn't base my decision on who is president. And I certainly don't believe Obama had anything to do with the crash based on when it occurred. But I sold this week because the PEG ratio is very high compared to other financials right now and there are still issues ahead. I remain bullish long term for BAC but I believe a pull-back will be coming. Then I'll buy back in. I have no crystal ball, so I'll accept the outcome of my own decision. I base my decisions on facts and analysis. I hope voters do the same. And I sincerely hope this seizure of the BAC board by political mudslingers returns to rational discussions about our hopes for BAC. But while we're mixing politics with banking, it is interesting that BAC made a sizable campaign contribution to one of our candidates. So to try to inspire fact-checking, I'll let those who care about truth investigate it for themselves to find out which candidate BAC is backing. We must learn that facts trump wild mudslinging.

Message.Title: Obama's Benghazi investigator tied to Hamas, Soros
Message.Msg: JERUSALEM – The Obama administration’s lead investigator into the Benghazi attack, former Ambassador Thomas Pickering, previously held clandestine meetings with Hamas aimed at opening U.S. dialogue with the terrorist group, according to informed Middle Eastern security officials. Sources within Hamas previously disclosed to WND the June 2009 meeting. The gathering allegedly took place in Geneva with two Hamas leaders, Bassem Naim and Mahmoud al-Zahar. Naim is Hamas’ health minister, while al-Zahar is one of the main Hamas leaders in Gaza. Pickering is further tied to the revolutions in the Middle East and North Africa through his role as a member of the small board of the International Crisis Group, or ICG, one of the main proponents of the international “Responsibility to Protect” doctrine. The doctrine is the very military protocol used to justify the NATO bombing campaign that brought down Moammar Ghadafi’s regime in Libya. Gareth Evans, president emeritus of the ICG, is the founder and co-author of the doctrine. Billionaire activist George Soros is on the ICG’s executive board. Soros’ Open Society Institute is also one of only three nongovernmental funders of the Global Centre for the Responsibility to Protect, the group that devised the doctrine. The ICG itself has long petitioned for talks with Hamas as well as normalized relations with the Muslim Brotherhood, for years urging the Egyptian government to allow the Brotherhood to establish an Islamist political party, as WND previously reported. The crisis group has petitioned for the Algerian government to cease “excessive” military activities against al-Qaida-linked groups and to allow organizations seeking to create an Islamic state to participate in the Algerian government.

Topic.Title: Exposing the myth of Republican superiority in business and economics

Message.Msg: You responded to MY post, but begin with "some of you hotshots in the 'bama camp..."? I speak for no one but myself, so don't bother manufacturing an imaginary legion of allies for me, and then trying to lump me in with them. Furthermore, your attempt to portray me as some sort of Obama camp follower is at once ludicrous and disingenuous; I've donated exactly nothing - money, time, or services - to Obama's campaign or to any candidate in any party in any electoral contest this year. Your exhortation for me to "get out of the academic environment and experience the reality of the big picture" is equally ridiculous and misguided; perhaps you automatically equate being well-read, intelligent, and articulate with having an ivory-tower perspective. The closest connection to academia that this non-degreed engineer and author has is a wife who teaches special-needs science in a local public high school, and a daughter who provides occupational therapy services to autistic children (K 6th grade) in the Phoenix public school system. Their careers in social services are about as far away from my own interests and abilities and background as they could possible be. I'm a tech geek, and I got what knowledge and skills by doing, not by taking courses. I was born in hillybillyville, western Pennsylvania; served as an enlisted grunt in the Air Force during the Vietnam era; and in addition to a pair of careers as a test engineer and author, I've owned and operated a small auto detailing business, sold motorcycles on commission, painted houses for a living, and taught fishing to children at a nearby day camp. It's quite a stretch to turn a resume like mine into some sort of elitist pedigree or socialist philosophy. Now that I've chased most of the straw dogs out of your monologue, I'll address what remains. Capitalism is indeed what built America, but there are many flavors of capitalism, and history is rife with examples of how bad some kinds of capitalism taste to the average citizen. Unrestrained and unregulated capitalism produced vast fortunes for a select few who financed and owned the whaling industry, the China Trade, and the railroad and coal and oil and steel industries; but their workers were treated and paid little better than indentured servants or slaves. That kind of capitalism, with its attendant speculation, boom-and-bust cycles, and reward for cutthroat competition and monopoly, bore fruit that included the near-extermination of the Indians and too many species of wildlife to list; slavery; the Panics of 1873 and 1907 (the later a currency crises manufactured by a few wealthy bankers to advance their goal of established a privatized central banking system they could control, the Federal Reserve), the euphemistically labeled "Golden Age", and the Great Depression. On the other hand, some capitalists recognized that a strong and sustainable economy is not possible unless wealth and opportunities are distributed among the larger population rather than being amassed by an elite and privileged few. If wealth is distributed more equitably in the first place, there is no need to 're-distribute' it. Henry Ford got that; do you think a guy with a heart as wizened as Mr. Burns' decided to pay his workers more than the prevailing wages because he felt sorry for them? He saw the "big picture", and so do I. You can't build a stable and sustainable economy if only a select few have enough chips to participate in it, and lacking a stable and sustainable economy, what hope can there be for the country that depends upon it? The economic crisis we face is that people are no longer viewed as assets, but as liabilities, commodities whose value is dropping fast as the need for human labor is displaced by the increasing reliance of business upon computers and machines. I was among the first people I know who pointed at the emerging "service economy" and recognized it as the harbinger of death for the American middle class, so you can skip the lecture about not seeing the big picture. You've given quite a lesson, 'drawn', quite unintentionally I'm sure, about the perils of generalizing, but I'm going to leave you with a generalization that made quite an impression on me, and one that I've found useful in understanding what drives the differences in policies and philosophies of the Republican and Democratic parties and their followers. When I was about 12, I already had a vague sense that the Democrats were the Good Guys, and the Republicans were the Bad Guys, but I understood next to nothing about politics or philosophy, and certainly couldn't explain why I felt the way I did. One day I was listening to my grandfather discussing Truman's upset victory over Tom Dewey with one of his friends. I screwed up my nerve, interrupted two grown-ups, and addressing my grandfather by his first name as was my habit, I asked him: "Tom, what's the difference between Republicans and Democrats?" He thought about it for a minute, and then gave this answer: "Well, kid, Democrats don't think they're any better than anyone else." ROTFLMAO his answer, and its implied but unstated corollary, are just as true today as they were then. Labels like 'socialist' and 'fascist' are just fig leaves used to hide this ugly but undeniable truth.
